conclusion: The two pieces of fabric (A on the left, B on the right) are held in the air.
Four rigid blocks are already on the table: C and D under the left fabric, E and F under the right fabric.

premise: The supports are removed; gravity accelerates both fabrics straight down toward the blocks.
conclusion: Objects A and B move towards the objects C, D, E, and F.

premise: Left side: fabric A touches the taller edges of blocks C and D, stopping its downward motion at those points.
conclusion: Fabric A makes contact with blocks C and D.

premise: Right side: fabric B touches the top of the taller block F first, then very shortly afterward touches block E.
conclusion: Fabric B makes contact with blocks E and F.

premise: Each cloth continues to sink in any open gaps until the material has nowhere lower to go.
conclusion: The fabrics drape over the blocks.

premise: Fabric A drapes over the tops of C and D and forms a sagging valley in the space between / around them.
conclusion: Fabric A covers blocks C and D.

premise: Fabric B stretches over the high edge of F, then drapes down to lie on E and spills into the lower area of table between the two blocks.
conclusion: Fabric B covers blocks E and F.

premise: Friction and the pinned corners bring both fabrics to rest.
The final shapes show the silhouettes of the underlying blocks: small plateaus where the fabric rests on the block tops, and smooth folds between them.
conclusion: The fabrics conform to the shapes of the blocks.

premise: After they are dropped, fabric A ends up neatly draped over blocks C and D, while fabric B ends up draped over blocks E and F, forming folds and valleys that follow the heights of the blocks underneath; all objects come to rest with the fabric conforming to the shapes of the four blocks and the table surface.
conclusion: Both Object A and Object B knock over the objects C, D, E and F and cover them.
